content.title: Neurogenic Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (NTOS)
content.definition: Compression of the brachial plexus at the thoracic outlet causing upper extremity pain, paresthesias, and weakness. The most common form of TOS (95% of cases), but also the most controversial due to subjective symptoms and lack of definitive diagnostic tests.

key_concepts.description: Brachial plexus compressed between anterior and middle scalene muscles, first rib, and clavicle. C8-T1 (lower trunk) most commonly affected
True neurogenic TOS (rare, <1%): objective findings, nerve conduction abnormalities; Disputed/common neurogenic TOS: subjective symptoms, normal EMG/NCS
Young adults (20-40); female predominance (3-4:1); often history of trauma, repetitive activity, or poor posture
Pain and paresthesias in neck, shoulder, arm, and hand; worse with overhead activity; C8-T1 distribution (ulnar) most common; may have headache, facial pain
Rare (<1%); objective weakness and atrophy of thenar and hypothenar muscles (Gilliatt-Sumner hand); abnormal EMG/NCS; often cervical rib or fibrous band
Provocative tests: Adson (pulse change with head turn), Roos (3-minute elevated arm stress test - most specific), Wright, costoclavicular. Tenderness over scalenes
Elevated arm stress test: patient opens and closes hands for 3 minutes with arms abducted 90°, externally rotated. Reproduction of symptoms or early fatigue is positive
Chest X-ray for cervical rib (present in only 10-20%); MRI for brachial plexus; X-ray with arms elevated may show dynamic compression
Physical therapy (strengthen shoulder girdle, improve posture), NSAIDs, muscle relaxants, activity modification. Successful in 50-70% of patients
First rib resection (transaxillary or supraclavicular) with anterior scalenectomy for refractory cases; cervical rib excision if present. Results variable (50-90% improvement)
Disputed NTOS lacks objective findings; diagnosis relies on symptom pattern and exclusion of other causes; some question whether it exists as distinct entity

explanation.intuition: Understanding Neurogenic Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (NTOS) helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Neurogenic Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (NTOS) include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.

learning_objectives: Define neurogenic TOS and distinguish from vascular TOS
Recognize true neurogenic TOS (Gilliatt-Sumner hand) vs disputed NTOS
Know provocative tests especially Roos test
Understand conservative management is first-line (50-70% success)
clinical_pearls: NTOS is 95% of TOS cases but most controversial
True NTOS is rare (<1%) - has objective EMG/NCS findings
Disputed NTOS has normal EMG - diagnosis of exclusion
Roos test (EAST) = 3 min arms up + hand opening/closing
Cervical rib only present in 10-20% of NTOS
common_mistakes: Operating on disputed NTOS without adequate conservative trial
Confusing NTOS symptoms with cervical radiculopathy or carpal tunnel
Expecting cervical rib in all cases (most don't have one)
Not recognizing true NTOS (look for thenar atrophy)
